docs.title: FastAPI Reverse Proxy with Keycloak Authentication
docs.text: A FastAPI-based reverse proxy that secures backend services with Keycloak authentication and dynamically routes requests using Kubernetes/OpenShift.

docs.title: 🚀 Features
docs.text:
• Keycloak authentication enforcement with JWT
  • Asynchronous request forwarding via httpx
  • Dynamic routing using DNS & environment variables
  • Secure session management including logout handling
  • Containerized with Podman & Docker
  • Supports OpenShift/Kubernetes deployments
  • MkDocs-based GitHub Pages documentation

docs.title: 📖 Documentation Sections
docs.text:
• Installation → Setting up dependencies and local development
  • Configuration → Managing environment variables & OpenShift setup
  • Authentication → Keycloak integration, login, and logout handling
  • Deployment → Running with Podman, Docker, and Kubernetes
  • API Reference → Proxy and authentication endpoints

🔗 Source Code: GitHub Repository

docs.title: Contributing: contributing.md
docs.text:
# Contributing to FastAPI Reverse Proxy

Contributions are welcome. Follow this guide to ensure consistency and quality.

---

## How to Contribute
### 1. Fork and Clone
```bash
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/fastapi-reverse-proxy.git
cd fastapi-reverse-proxy

docs.title: 4. Make Changes and Test
docs.text:
• Follow code style guidelines (black, isort).
  • Run the application: bash uvicorn app:app --reload
  • Run tests: bash pytest

docs.title: 5. Commit and Push
docs.text:
git add .
git commit -m "Add feature XYZ"
git push origin feature/your-feature-name

docs.title: 6. Submit a Pull Request
docs.text:
• Open a pull request on GitHub.
  • Follow the pull request template.
  • Ensure CI checks pass.

docs.title: Code Guidelines
docs.text:
• Follow PEP8 and Black formatting.
  • Use meaningful commit messages.
  • Write docstrings and type hints.
  • Keep changes small and focused.

docs.title: Issues and Discussions
docs.text:
• Check existing issues before creating a new one.
  • Use discussions for feature ideas.
  • Provide clear steps to reproduce bugs.

docs.title: License
docs.text: By contributing, you agree that your code will be under the MIT License. ```
